questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. He mentions that he recently returned from a camping trip. Stool examination reveals the presence of helminths. Which of the following is least likely to be responsible for autoinfection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hymenolepis diminuta

 

Option D:

 

Hymenolepis diminuta is the least likely to be responsible for autoinfection. This tapeworm typically requires an intermediate host for transmission and does not commonly cause autoinfection in humans.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Strongyloides: Incorrect because Strongyloides stercoralis is known for its ability to cause autoinfection in humans.

 

Option B) Taenia solium: Incorrect as Taenia solium can lead to autoinfection, particularly when cysticercosis occurs.

 

Option C) Hymenolepis nana: Incorrect as Hymenolepis nana can cause autoinfection in humans, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autoinfection is seen in CHEST: Cryptosporidium, H.nana, Enterobius, Strongyloides and T.solium.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Parasitology 1/e p6, 2/e p5

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a parasitic infection acquired through the consumption of raw fish. Which of the following parasites, known to use fish as an intermediate host, is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphyllobothrium latum

 

Option A:

 

Diphyllobothrium latum, also known as the fish tapeworm, uses fish as an intermediate host. Infection occurs through the consumption of raw or undercooked infected fish.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Clonorchis sinensis: Incorrect, although it also uses fish as an intermediate host, D. latum is more directly associated with raw fish consumption.

 

Option C) Hymenolepis diminuta: Incorrect, does not use fish as an intermediate host.

 

Option D) Hymenolepis nana: Incorrect, does not use fish as an intermediate host.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parasites with an indirect/complex life cycle that require one definitive host and two intermediate hosts

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p163, 207,2/e p129,165

questions.text:
A 40-year-old farmer from a rural area in Bihar, India, presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of fever, weight loss, and enlargement of his abdomen. Physical examination reveals significant hepatosplenomegaly. A complete blood count shows pancytopenia. A bone marrow aspirate is performed for definitive diagnosis. 

 

 

Which of the following findings in the bone marrow aspirate is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leishman-Donovan bodies

 

Option C:

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are the intracellular amastigotes of Leishmania parasites, commonly seen in the macrophages of bone marrow aspirates. Their presence is diagnostic of visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), which is endemic in Bihar and consistent with the patient's clinical presentation of fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia.

 

 

Figure: L. donovani amastigotes: showing a macrophage containing multiple Leishmania amastigotes. A. Schematic; B. In bone marrow smear stained with Giemsa. Note that each amastigote has a nucleus (red arrow) and a rod-shaped kinetoplast (black arrow).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Reed-Sternberg cells are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma, not associated with the symptoms or endemic disease in Bihar.

 

Option B) Schistocytes are fragmented red cells typically seen in hemolytic anemias and not indicative of visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Option D) Auer rods are seen in acute myeloid leukemia, which does not align with the patient's clinical presentation and epidemiological context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies in bone marrow aspirates as a key diagnostic feature of visceral leishmaniasis, especially in endemic areas like Bihar, India. Recognizing the clinical presentation of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and pancytopenia in conjunction with these findings is crucial for diagnosing and managing this disease.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p317

choices.text: Single ring form in P. vivax
Multiple ring forms in P. falciparum

questions.text: A 30-year-old male, who recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region, presents with intermittent fever, chills, and headache. His blood smear is examined under the microscope for malaria parasites. Which of the following findings is NOT typically associated with the peripheral blood smear of malaria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enlarged erythrocytes in P. falciparum

 

Option D:

 

In malaria, P. vivax infection is characterized by the presence of enlarged erythrocytes, but this is not a feature of P. falciparum infection. P. falciparum typically shows multiple ring forms within a single erythrocyte and does not cause erythrocyte enlargement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Single ring form in P. vivax – This is correct as P. vivax usually shows a single ring form per erythrocyte.

 

Option B) Multiple ring forms in P. falciparum – This is a characteristic feature of P. falciparum and is true.

 

Option C) Enlarged erythrocytes in P. vivax – True, as P. vivax is known to cause enlargement of infected erythrocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e p76

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, recently diagnosed with malaria, is being treated in a healthcare facility. To prevent the transmission of the disease, the treating physician is considering a medication that is effective against the gametocyte stage of all malaria species. Which of the following medications is known to be gametocidal for all Plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primaquine

 

Option C:

 

Primaquine is the only antimalarial drug that is effective against the gametocyte stage of all Plasmodium species. The gametocyte stage is crucial in the transmission of malaria from humans to the mosquito vector. By targeting this stage, primaquine plays a key role in preventing the spread of malaria. This property distinguishes it from other antimalarial drugs like quinine and chloroquine, which are primarily effective against different stages of the parasite's life cycle within the human host.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Quinine – While effective against asexual forms of the parasite, it is not gametocidal for all species.

 

Option B) Chloroquine – Targets asexual blood stages of Plasmodium but is not effective against all gametocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primaquine is the only antimalarial drug that is effective against the gametocyte stage of all Plasmodium species, making it crucial in preventing the spread of malaria.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e p86, KDT Pharmacology 7/e p821

questions.text: A recent breakthrough in malaria research has led to the development of a new vaccine strain targeting Plasmodium falciparum. This advancement is discussed among healthcare professionals, emphasizing its potential impact on malaria prevention. Which of the following is a new Plasmodium falciparum vaccine strain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RTS,S/AS01

 

Option B:

 

RTS,S/AS01, known as Mosquirix, is the first and currently the only vaccine showing efficacy against Plasmodium falciparum in clinical trials. It is a recombinant protein based vaccine. It has been approved by the FDA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) PPV23 – This is a pneumococcal vaccine, not related to malaria.

 

Option C) R14-4 – Not a recognized malaria vaccine strain.

 

Option D) NYVAC-PF01 – While a potential vaccine candidate, it does not have the established efficacy of RTS, S/AS01.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various malaria vaccine with the site of action and names


 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Parasitology 1st e/p113, 2/e p89, Malaria vaccines since 2000: progress, priorities, products- Duffy, P.E., Patrick Gorres, J. Malaria vaccines since 2000: progress, priorities, products. npj Vaccines 5, 48 (2020). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41541-020-0196-3

choices.text: They are sequestered in the spleen
Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood
Due to antigen-antibody reaction and removal, antibody-dependent cytotoxic killing
They are seen in mosquito blood

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the life cycle of Plasmodium falciparum and its presentation in blood smears. Why are schizont and late trophozoite stages of Plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smears?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood

 

Option B:

 

P. falciparum gets sequestrated by adhering to the endothelium of deep vessels. After the ring forms are formed, the remaining part of RBC cycle of P. falciparum occurs in deep vessels (not in peripheral blood. This is the reason why schizont and late trophozoite stages are not seen in peripheral blood smear.

 

 

Figure: A. P. falciparum ring forms such as multiple rings (blue arrow), accole form (red arrow) and head phone-shaped ring form (black arrow); B. Female gametocyte of P. falciparum; C. Male gametocyte of P. falciparum

 

Life cycle of Plasmodium

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. They are sequestered in the spleen – Partially true, but the main reason is adherence to the endothelium.

 

Option C. Due to antigen-antibody reaction – This does not primarily account for their absence in smears.

 

Option D. They are seen in mosquito blood – Not relevant to their absence in human peripheral blood smears.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In P. falciparum infections, schizonts and late trophozoites stick to the capillary endothelium, causing their absence in peripheral blood smears as they are sequestered in organs. Other factors like spleen sequestration and antigen-antibody reactions play lesser roles, and their presence in mosquito blood is unrelated to their absence in human smears.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Parasitology/p94, 2/e p77

questions.text: A healthcare professional is conducting a training session on blood safety and the risks of transfusion-associated infections, including malaria. Which form of the malaria parasite is responsible for transfusion-associated malaria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trophozoite

 

Option A:

 

Transfusion-associated malaria is typically caused by the trophozoite form of the parasite. These forms are present in the infected donor's blood and can be transmitted through blood transfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sporozoites – These are the forms injected by mosquitoes, not typically found in transfused blood.

 

Option C. Female gametocyte – Not the primary infective form in transfusions.

 

Option D. Male gametocyte – Like female gametocytes, not the primary infective form in transfusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infective form of Plasmodium

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Parasitology/p101, 2/e p72

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of recurring fever every 72 hours. This periodicity of fever is characteristic in malaria cases. Based on this specific fever pattern, which Plasmodium species is most likely responsible for the patient's malaria infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) P. malariae

 

Option D:

 

Plasmodium malariae is known to cause a quartan fever pattern, with the fever recurring every 72 hours. This is due to the parasite's 72-hour erythrocytic cycle. The periodicity of fever in malaria is related to the life cycle of the Plasmodium species in red blood cells. Each species has a different duration for its erythrocytic cycle, which determines the fever pattern. P. malariae's quartan fever pattern is distinct from the other Plasmodium species, making it the likely causative agent in this case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. P. falciparum – Typically causes malignant tertian malaria (severe malaria, periodicity of fever is once in 48 hours, recurs every third day).

 

Option B. P. vivax – Causes benign tertian malaria (periodicity of fever is once in 48 hours, i.e. recurs every third day)

 

Option C. P. ovale – Causes ovale tertian malaria (periodicity of fever is once in 48 hours, i.e. recurs every third day)

 

Note – 

 

  • P. knowlesi causes quotidian or simian malaria (fever periodicity is once in 24 hours, i.e. recurs every day). It is a parasite of monkey but can also infect humans and many cases affecting man were recently reported from Asia.
  • R-G interval: Time between the release of sporozoites by the mosquito and the appearance of gametocytes in the blood
  • Extrinsic Incubation Period (IP): Time taken for the development of parasites in the mosquito.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other differences between the species of Plasmodium:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p96, 2/e p75

choices.text: Reappearance of sexual stage parasitemia after treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, who had been diagnosed with Plasmodium falciparum malaria, completed a course of treatment with chloroquine. Two weeks after the completion of her treatment, she returns to the clinic with a recurrence of symptoms, including fever, headache, and malaise. Blood tests reveal the presence of malaria parasites. Her case is presented at a medical conference to discuss the challenges in malaria treatment and the potential reasons for the reappearance of symptoms. What is the most likely cause of the reappearance of her malaria symptoms after treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Resistance to treatment

 

Option A:

 

Recrudescence in malaria, particularly in the case of P. falciparum, often occurs due to resistance to antimalarial drugs. In this patient's scenario, the return of symptoms and the presence of parasites post-treatment suggest that the parasite was not completely eradicated initially, likely due to drug resistance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Relapse of infection – Typically associated with P. vivax and P. ovale due to their dormant liver stages, not P. falciparum.

 

Option C. Relapse in vivax and ovale – As above, this is more specific to P. vivax and P. ovale.

 

Option D. Reappearance of sexual stage parasitemia after treatment – This is more indicative of treatment failure or reinfection rather than recrudescence.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p93, 2/e p73

questions.text: A 35-year-old male in India presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of high fever, severe headache, and episodes of vomiting. He has recently returned from a rural area with known malaria transmission. On examination, he is febrile (39.5°C, disoriented, and experiencing seizures. Laboratory tests confirm a high parasitemia of Plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cerebral malaria

 

Option C:

 

Cerebral malaria is characterized by seizures, altered consciousness, and high fever in the context of P. falciparum infection. Cerebral malaria manifests as diffuse symmetric encephalopathy characterized by repeated seizures, reduced muscle tone and tendon reflexes Seizures are more common in children (up to 50%) than in adults (10%)

 

Pathogenesis: P. falciparum exhibit unique property of being sequestered inside the brain capillaries due to PfEMP (P. falciparum erythrocyte membrane protein-1), results in plugging of brain capillaries leading to vascular occlusion and cerebral anoxia

 

Laboratory diagnosis: Peripheral blood smear examination is the gold standard method to identify P. falciparum (Banana-shaped gametocytes); Quantitative buffy coat examination and Rapid diagnostic tests (ICT detecting P. falciparum specific HRP-II antigen).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Viral encephalitis – Although presenting with similar neurological symptoms, the presence of high P. falciparum parasitemia makes cerebral malaria more likely.

 

Option B. Bacterial meningitis – Meningitis typically presents with neck stiffness, photophobia, and might not coincide with P. falciparum parasitemia.

 

Option D. Heat stroke – While it can cause altered mental status and high body temperature, it does not explain the high parasitemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria, linked to P. falciparum infection, is marked by seizures, altered consciousness, and high fever. It involves the sequestration of parasitized RBCs in brain capillaries, causing vascular occlusion and cerebral anoxia. This condition, more common in children, can lead to encephalopathy, retinal hemorrhages, and a high mortality rate. Diagnosis is typically made through peripheral blood smear examination, revealing characteristic P. falciparum forms. 

 

Ref: Paniker’s parasitology 7/e p77, Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p100, 2/e p78

questions.text: During a workshop on vector-borne diseases, there is a discussion on the transmission mechanisms of various pathogens, including Babesiosis. Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ticks

 

Option D:

 

  • Babesiosis is a malaria like illness seen in cattle and sheep.
  • B. microti is the most common species, others being B. bovis and B. divergens.
  •  It is similar to malaria parasite in its life cycle and pathogenesis except for the following differences:
    •  Hard tick (Ixodes scapularis) is the primary vector (definitive host) of the parasite
    • There is no liver-stage, sporozoites enter directly into RBCs
    • Clinical feature: It differs from falciparum malaria being less severe, low parasitemia, no cerebral involvement, less severe anemia and no periodicity seen in fever cycle.
  • More severe in splenectomized and immunocompromised patients

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, Option B, Option C - Pigs, rats, and sand flies are not common vectors for the transmission of Babesia parasites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by deer tick (hard tick) Ixodes scapularis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e, p90
